11 May 2009, Monday morning when my alarm rang.

“Ugh, mondays...” I sighed.

This is just another new start of the week for a computer geek who always went to bed late, because he was so stuck into playing those online games.

“Right, let's get ready for school.” As my 17 year old body stood out of the bed I was lying in.

“Let's check my mail first...”

So I sat down in my chair behind the computer and turned the screen on. Since I always left my PC on I didn't need to turn the PC on and wait a darn long time before it finally was ready for use.

And so when the screen was on I clicked my email program to check my usual routine of sorting my mail first...

“Spam, spam... Jeez what a crapload of spam today” I said to myself.

That until I noticed a strange mail with an empty sender with the subject “Tired of not being in control of your life?”

“What the..., How can that be?” I thought and opened up the mail inside.

“
Hi Peter,

Tired of not being in control of your life?
Ever thought of even controlling your surroundings?

Well now you can!

Along with this e-mail we've sent you an application that let's YOU be in control!
So why wait and check it out fast?”

“Right, this looks like some new virus mail...” I thought to myself at first. But even normally these virus mails even have a sender. So I went ahead and saved the attachment to my harddisk. But before opening up the installer file I scanned the file first with the virus scanner first.

And after a few minutes the results came in from the scan.

“No virus found!” It read on my screen.
“Wow, cool not a virus. Then this might be even safe...” So I went and opened up the installer file.

“Welcome to Master PC! The tool that let's you be in control”
“Please choose an install location:”

So I choose a path to install this Master PC to my disk. And after a few minutes it was installed. A few minutes later I was sitting infront of a screen telling me to set a password for the program. Now since I was pretty lazy in remembering passwords and all I choose the frontname of my girlfriend with the year my younger sister was born in. “Melinda1994” I typed in.

And after a few loading bars I was sitting behind my PC looking at the screen showing my profile.

At the top of the screen was my full name, date of birth and current location.
Look a bit left I saw a 3d model of me so photo realistic looking as I never had seen any game before doing that. The model even had the clothes I was currently wearing. Although that wasn't that much yet, since I still had to dress up for college.

On the first side there were a few tabs with each a different body part of me. But the first tab was some sort of overview of basic information about my body. Like a gender Male/Female radio button box where the male gender was highlighted. An age textbox saying 17 years old , weight saying 176 pounds, height saying 6'1” and even more stuff on it. There was even a textbox telling what I was doing at this moment.

In the bottom there was a button 'Apply' as if the settings above could be saved somehow.

11.content:
At this point, I was more than a little freaked out. Being able to know who I was was one thing, but being able to get such a realistic shot of my figure was still creepy. And even knowing the clothes I was wearing? What the hell?

I tore my eyes away from the computer screen, looking for I-don't-know-what. I didn't know if this was a prank, or a trick, or anything else for matter. Well, I didn't see any security cameras in the room, and my roommate was already gone for classes- he wouldn't be back until late in the afternoon. I was still suspicious, but going this far, it seemed a little silly and pointless to go back.

I looked at this realistic rendering of me on the computer, and decided to test something, just to see what this was about. In all likelihood, this was probably just some sort of character-editing program, using the player to add a certain touch of realism. A Sims character creator.

A really, really odd character creator.

Well, whatever. I looked at the box which surrounded my image's spare hand- the one not using the mouse. I clicked on one of the corners of the box, and dragged it outwards a little, causing it drastically increase its ratio to my character's body. Suddenly...

FOOMPH!

"HOLY shit!" I cried out loud, with none of my neighbors listening or caring. My hand had ballooned to over three times its original size. I was so surprised that I fell backwards out of my chair. I just laid there, staring at it incredulously. It felt no different than usual, maybe a little numb in the extremities, but my hand was definitely not its usual self. It was as easy to control as always, but stood comically oversized on my small wrist. I can't find a good comparison for it. Imagine putting on a foam finger which turns into your hand, or being one of those cartoon characters who gives a massive punch which turns his fist gigantic. That's sort of what my hand was like. It was the same hand, same feeling, but it had grown, like it was put under a magnifying glass.

...Grown. Like my avatar's hand.

I stood up without much effort, flexed my hand experimentally, then went to my avatar on the computer program. It stood there motionlessly, with its comically oversized hand. None of the numbers for weight or height had changed, but a new column next to them saying "realistic weight" showed that I'd gained about fifty or sixty pounds. The original column's numbers said "actual weight". It couldn't be.... could it?

I cautiously clicked on the corner of the box my avatar's hand was in, and slowly dragged it down until the "realistic weight" was equal to the "actual weight".

Sure enough, my gigantic hand slowly shrank down to its original proportions.

"...Holy shit," I repeated quietly. "Just... what... how.... who?"

I only had just tasted the power I now had at my hands.

1133122.content:
I grinned a bit as I chose the "Alter DNA" option.

The screen of my PDA said "done" pretty quickly, but I really couldn't see any difference. Well, maybe her hair was a little brighter pink, but it was hard to tell.

I shrugged and walked away, starting to think of other things I might do with this Master PC program.

When I passed another study carrel, I did a double-take and stopped. The male student sitting there hunched over a book, who looked otherwise perfectly normal, had hair that was turquoise, literally. In the carrel next to that sat a girl whose hair was darker, more of a midnight blue -- but it was blue, not black.

I went by Alice again. Her hair was no longer the muted orangish-red that one might think of as "red hair"; now it was a bright orange, the color of a safety vest.

I ducked into a convenient men's room, and saw myself in the mirror above the sinks. I had green hair, about the color of a can of 7-Up. I gawked at myself, running my fingers through my hair several times -- of course, it felt perfectly normal.

"Excuse me." I had to step aside so a guy who'd come out of one of the stalls could wash his hands. His hair was also green, but more of a forest green. I wanted to ask him, "Dude, did you know your hair was green?", but I figured that he'd think I was crazy.

I left the restroom and walked to the library's reference room, where there were long tables instead of individual carrels. Plenty of students were sitting and studying. A few of them had what I thought of as "regular" hair colors -- black, brown, blonde -- but everyone else looked like their hair color had been chosen randomly from a giant box of crayons. I even saw one girl with hair that looked gold. Race didn't seem to play a factor -- there was an Asian guy with almost the same shade as me, for example.

It occurred to me to check my driver's license, so I pulled my wallet out of my back pocket to take a look. There I was with the green hair, in a photograph taken a couple years ago. And it was there in print, too: "Hair GRN, eyes BLU."

Curious, and since I was in the reference room anyway, I thought about looking at a book of old photographs, but realized those would probably be in black-and-white. So I went up to the African-American woman at the desk -- she had hair about the same auburn color that I'd briefly given to the punk chick -- and asked about an art history book with lots of illustrations.

She pointed me in the right direction. I took it down from the shelves and opened it, and happened to turn straight to a section on DaVinci.

Where I saw the Mona Lisa.

She had bright purple hair.

That was when it really hit me what I'd done -- or, rather, how the Master PC had handled it when I'd told it to "alter DNA" in order to allow for the possibility of natural pink hair.

I had to decide: did I want to try to undo it (although I'd been warned that it might not be easily undoable), or did I want to keep the world with these strange and varied hair colors?

11331222.content:
I decided against trying to return things to normal. This was a little weird, but it seemed to be more-or-less harmless; who knew what would happen if I tried to change things back?

I spent way too long in the periodicals section, looking at -- well, everything. It was kind of interesting to find out what color hair everyone had now. The cover of 'People' showed me that Jennifer Aniston had dark green hair, while Kim Kardashian's was pure white. A back issue of 'Newsweek' revealed Barack Obama's hair as a light navy blue. The weirdest thing was some of the animals; apparently, in order to change humans, the master PC had had to make changes pretty far back in mammalian development. A National Geographic feature on the Alaskan grizzly followed a fire-engine-red mama bear and her green and purple cubs. They look like giant, deadly Care Bears.

It was nearly an hour before I realized 1) as bizarre as this was, it was really nothing you couldn't do with Photoshop, so why was I wasting my time with magazines? and 2) especially when I had the power to alter reality in my pocket?

I walked back into the main room of the library, my head spinning with possibilities. As I passed by the punk girl from earlier, I noticed something that hadn't been obvious from the front; the back of her hair was trimmed very short, with elaborate designs shaved into it. I was taken aback for a moment. Had I done that, somehow? Or hell, had it always been like that, even before I changed a thing? I looked around. It did seem as if a few more students than usual had exotic hairstyles. Not a majority, but more than I would have expected. One girl had a (blue) mohawk tied into a row of pigtails, and there was a guy with the top of his head shaved bald, like a medieval monk or something.

I wondered if I was responsible, and after a minute I decided maybe it was because people couldn't dye their hair odd colors to stand out anymore; there were no odd colors. So they had to do other things. That made as much sense as anything; it wasn't like I could ask someone if I was right.

Well, so far, so good. Now I had to think of another test for the Master PC.
11331222.title: But What Of Rollen Stewart?

choices: Time to get a little revenge on someone!
113312222.content:
I was getting pretty curious about the Master PC's ability to "justify" anything I might put in. If it could change the history of human evolution -- even just in regards to one trivial thing like hair color -- what else could it do to reorder the world around the changes I made?

I thought about it for a moment, and came up with what I thought was a pretty good test.

Last week, the school paper had profiled Lindsey Culver, a sophomore who'd taken first place in the state track tournament. I picked up a copy from the library and doubled-checked it. She said in the story that she liked eating lunch under a tree on the north quad when the weather was nice, and that's where I found her, parked in the shade of a sycamore.

She had a perfect runner's body: tall and slender, with legs like a gazelle. Her hair was a yellowish-green that might have looked a little seasick in the wrong light, but suited her complexion well; actually better than the plain blonde she'd had the first time I'd seen her picture. I skimmed the article again, looking for salient pieces of information. Running awards since middle school, blah blah blah, strict training diet, etc. etc. What if I made it so that the current Lindsey was incompatible with the story in the paper? Would the headline change, like in Back to the Future?

I watched her bring a carrot stick to her mouth and nibble on it. She didn't see me watching her from the sidewalk; she was engrossed in a dogeared paperback. I felt a little bad about what I was going to do; she seemed like a perfectly nice person. I promised myself I would reverse it as soon as I was finished; nobody would ever know, not even her.

I brought her up on the screen and combed through the variables until I found the one I wanted. WEIGHT. She wasn't exactly feather-light, being tall and well-muscled, but she didn't have an ounce of fat on her. I decided to change that.

I moved the slider a single click, just enough to make the number go up by one. I guess she gained a pound, but I didn't see any difference. I tried a larger jump; five pounds. I still couldn't really tell. Another five pounds. It showed a little on her now; she was just slightly softer.

I glanced down at her profile in the paper. It had changed. Now instead of 'CULVER TAKES HOME GOLD AT STATE', it was a little smaller, and read 'CULVER TAKES SILVER MEDAL'.

She looked almost the same. Weird that it could make such a difference to her performance. I noticed she was now dipping her carrot sticks in a small container of dressing, and paged through the article. Sure enough, her strict training diet wasn't mentioned. This Lindsey was a little less disciplined.

Curious, I nudged her weight down again, keeping an eye on the paper. The heaviest she could be and still get first place was seven pounds above where she'd started, where she won in a photo finish. At eight pounds, it was also a photo finish, but she lost.

Now, what would happen if I went up a little more? I clicked the slider one pound at a time, watching her grow slowly and steadily. Although her clothes were supposed to change with her, I noticed they seemed to 'pulse', getting slightly tighter and then slightly looser every few pounds. I realized I was seeing her pass through different clothing size ranges -- they didn't make the sizes in gradations of one pound, after all.

I was so distracted by that that I didn't realize I'd put nearly fifty pounds onto her until I glanced down at the display, then at the paper. Way too much, obviously; she wasn't even mentioned at all. The headline was about a local politician's visit to campus; our lame performance at state was buried at the bottom of the sports page. This Lindsey was downright chubby. She could never even have qualified for the track team.

As I watched, she reached a hand into the greasy bag next to herself and pulled out a French fry. She nibbled on it in exactly the same way skinny Lindsey had nibbled the carrot. So she was still the same person; all the Master PC was doing was changing her eating habits. That made sense; same person, same metabolism, so the simplest way to change her weight was this.

I went up and down the scale again, this time watching what she was eating. That was interesting in its own right. At less than ten pounds below her starting weight, she ate nothing -- and she wasn't in the paper there, either, because she was clearly outright anoxeric, not an athlete. A few pounds up, and a small baggie of carrots appeared. A few more, and I was back to her original lunch: carrots, an apple, and a sandwich. A few more and the dressing appeared. Five more, and she had a baggie of chips. Five more, and there was a cookie. The twenty-five pound mark was where the fast food bag made its appearance, and it stayed for nearly forty pounds, as various snack cakes and candy packages began to appear next to her. Anything over that, and she was chowing down on a large deep-dish pizza.

I decided to say hello, and walked up to her casually, just as if I hadn't been standing there for ten minutes already. "Hi, uh, Lindsey, isn't it?"

"Mmph," she nodded. Most of a slice was in her mouth. She finished it hastily and swallowed, then wiped a bit of grease on a pale-blue tank top that was about a dozen sizes larger than it had started. "Do -- do I know you?"

"Didn't I see you in the paper? I thought I read about a Lindsey Culver who was in track."

She laughed, displaying beautiful -- if slightly sauce-stained -- teeth. "Do I look like a track star?"

"I bet you could be a great one; you're got the right frame for it."

"Yeah -- but I'm not really -- in shape for it. You know?" She laughed again, a little nervously. I guess I was being a little weird, from her perspective.

"You never considered just eating less?"

"Gee," she said, rolling her eyes, "why didn't I think of that? Nobody's ever suggested that to me before. Look, it's not like I looooove being fat. If I could push a magic button and be thin, I would. But I can't, okay?"

"No, but I can."

"Huh?"

I didn't answer; I just touched my fingers to my PDA and dialed Lindsey all the way back to normal. It was a little like watching a balloon deflate; I was almost surprised there wasn't a cartoony pbbbt sound effect.

"--coming up to me all the time to talk about that article; it was so amazing to be in the paper! And everybody's just been saying how exciting it was!"

I guess we were having a conversation.

"Do you ever wish you didn't have to stay in shape for running?" I asked.

"Sometimes." She grinned; her smile was just as pretty in a thin face as a fat one, though she didn't have the dimples anymore. "Believe me, if I didn't have to keep trim, I'd probably eat a pizza every day and weigh like three hundred pounds."

"Nah." I winked at her. "Only two hundred."

She smiled again and licked a dollop of dressing off of her carrot stick.

Okay, I admit it. I let her keep seven of those extra pounds. After all, what's more exciting than a photo finish?

Well I think you all remember JR Parz's Master PC?

Well, Since it's not here as an interactive yet. Here it is!

Rules:

Just two:

-Add chapters, Heck I'll even reward you for additions
-Just keep the it more of a story with paths to chose than single lined question chapters.
